SubTopics: Demonstrate understanding of figurative language, word relationships, and nuances in word meanings.
Content: Read the sentence from the passage.
:box:“Then one night, as his classmates snored away, a brainwave hit Louis: the sounds were the problem.”
What does the phrase “a brainwave hit Louis” mean?

A.Choice: Louis was hit by a large wave of water.

Key.Rationale: The evidence in the passage does not support this idea.

B.Choice: Louis became soaked in a sudden thunderstorm.

Key.Rationale: The evidence in the passage does not support this idea.

C.Choice: Louis experienced a very deep sleep.

Key.Rationale: The evidence in the passage does not support this idea.

D.Choice: Louis came up with a new idea.

Key.Rationale: This option fits the context of the passage. The passage indicates that while Louis’s classmates were sleeping he figured out why his other ideas had not succeeded.

SubTopics: Determine or clarify the meaning of unknown and multiple-meaning words and phrases based on grade 5 reading and content, choosing flexibly from a range of strategies.
Content: The meaning of the root “-graph” helps the reader know that the word “paragraph” refers to something that is

A.Choice: in a pattern.

Key.Rationale: This option is not related to the given root word.

B.Choice: read aloud.

Key.Rationale: This option is not related to the given root word.

C.Choice: in writing.

Key.Rationale: The root word “-graph” means “writing.”

D.Choice: sounded out.

Key.Rationale: This option is not related to the given root word.

SubTopics: Demonstrate understanding of figurative language, word relationships, and nuances in word meanings.
Content: Read the sentence from the passage.
:box:“He knew what this meant: a fifteen-year-old boy had just switched on the light of learning for blind people forevermore.”
What does the metaphor “switched on the light of learning” mean?

A.Choice: A young man designed a tool that would make a great impact for people who were blind.

Key.Rationale: Louis created a tool that would have a long-lasting impact for blind people.

B.Choice: Dr. Pignier feels learning is very important for children whether they are at home or at school.

Key.Rationale: This option is a misinterpretation of the given metaphor and is not supported by the passage.

C.Choice: A fifteen-year-old boy invented a special light to help others see clearly while they read.

Key.Rationale: This option is a misinterpretation of the given metaphor and is not supported by the passage.

D.Choice: Dr. Pignier feels students who are blind should start school when they are fifteen years old.

Key.Rationale: This option is a misinterpretation of the given metaphor and is not supported by the passage.

Topics: Informational Text - Craft & Structure/Integration Of Knowledge & Ideas
SubTopics: Explain how an author uses reasons and evidence to support particular points in a text, identifying which reasons and evidence support which point(s).
Content: Which detail from the passage supports the point that young people who attended the Royal Institute recognized the value of the new system for reading before others did?

A.Choice: “Since braille letters could fit under a person’s fingertip . . .”

Key.Rationale: This option does not relate to the author’s point.

B.Choice: “. . . so the books weren’t so huge and expensive to produce.”

Key.Rationale: This option does not relate to the author’s point.

C.Choice: “They didn’t want to give up their old embossed letter system . . .”

Key.Rationale: This option does not relate to the author’s point.

D.Choice: “. . . many students were smuggling styluses into the school . . .”

Key.Rationale: The fact that students brought styluses to school, even when the director of the school refused to use braille, supports the idea that young people recognized the system’s value.

Topics: Informational Text - Craft & Structure/Integration Of Knowledge & Ideas
SubTopics: Interpret text features (e.g., headings, graphics, charts) and/or make connections between text and the content of text features.
Content: How does the information in the text box relate to the information in the passage?

A.Choice: by explaining what else Louis accomplished in his life

Key.Rationale: The text box provides information about Louis Braille’s other accomplishments, which included earning “a living playing music.”

B.Choice: by identifying the type of instruments Louis was able to play

Key.Rationale: This option is not an idea that relates the information in the text box to the passage.

C.Choice: by explaining why Louis wanted to attend the school for the blind

Key.Rationale: This option is not an idea that relates the information in the text box to the passage.

D.Choice: by identifying how Louis earned a living to pay for his school tuition

Key.Rationale: This option is not an idea that relates the information in the text box to the passage.

SubTopics: Determine two or more main ideas of a text and explain how they are supported by key details; summarize the text.
Content: What is the best summary of the passage?

A.Choice: While living at a school for the blind, Louis found a new way for blind people to read. Louis studied the new method, but he found problems in it. He worked day and night to fix the problems and became ill because he worked too much.

Key.Rationale: This option does not include all of the key ideas of the passage.

B.Choice: Although books for the blind had already been invented, Louis was not satisfied. He learned about sonography and worked to improve it. Eventually, Louis developed a system that would change reading for the blind forever.

Key.Rationale: This option includes the key ideas of the passage.

C.Choice: Louis Braille did not like the embossed books for the blind. They were big and had to be propped up on an easel. Louis knew that someday there would be a better way of writing for the blind.

Key.Rationale: This option does not include all of the key ideas of the passage.

D.Choice: Louis Braille lost his eyesight when he accidentally poked his eye with a tool and then spread the infection. He was only three years old. With the help of the village priest, Louis was sent to a school and learned to read.

Key.Rationale: This option does not include all of the key ideas of the passage.

SubTopics: Quote accurately from a text when explaining what the text says explicitly and when drawing inferences and/or making generalizations from the text.
Content: This question has two parts. Answer Part One and then answer Part Two.
What generalization can be made from information in the passage?

A.Choice: Sonography helped officers in wartime.

Key.Rationale: While this option includes ideas that can be supported with details in the passage, it is incorrect because it is not a generalization.

B.Choice: The French Royal Institute for Blind Youth used embossed books.

Key.Rationale: While this option includes ideas that can be supported with details in the passage, it is incorrect because it is not a generalization.

C.Choice: Louis Braille was satisfied with his accomplishments.

Key.Rationale: Louis Braille’s last words were “I am convinced that my mission on earth is finished,” which relate a sense of accomplishment.

D.Choice: Louis Braille earned enough money to make a living by playing music.

Key.Rationale: While this option includes ideas that can be supported with details in the passage, it is incorrect because it is not a generalization.

Content: Which detail from the passage best supports the answer in Part One? Choose one answer.

A.Choice: “. . . after the seven years of darkness since he’d lost his sight, Louis was excited.”

Key.Rationale: This option is an action that does not support a feeling of accomplishment.

B.Choice: “Sonography was so hard to use, many blind students gave up.”

Key.Rationale: This option is an action that does not support a feeling of accomplishment.

C.Choice: “Then, as the amazed director watched, Louis turned the paper over and read, with his fingertips . . . ”

Key.Rationale: This option describes a task that Louis completed but does not describe his feelings.

D.Choice: “. . . his last words were, ‘I am convinced that my mission on earth is finished.’ ”

SubTopics: Determine or clarify the meaning of unknown and multiple-meaning words and phrases based on grade 5 reading and content, choosing flexibly from a range of strategies.
Content: The meaning of the root “port” helps the reader know that the word “portable” means

A.Choice: able to be carried.

Key.Rationale: “Port” is a root that means “carry.”

B.Choice: able to speak on.

Key.Rationale: This option is not related to the given root word.

C.Choice: able to be shared.

Key.Rationale: This option is not related to the given root word.

D.Choice: able to hear through.

Key.Rationale: This option is not related to the given root word.

SubTopics: Demonstrate understanding of figurative language, word relationships, and nuances in word meanings.
Content: Read the sentences from the passage.
:box:“I guess the thought of taking my bike had been hanging around in my head for a while and I just didn’t know it. But it was there, plain as day, when I woke up.”
What does the simile “plain as day” describe?

A.Choice: something that happens again and again

Key.Rationale: This option is a misinterpretation of the given simile and does not support the context provided in the sentence.

B.Choice: something that takes a long time

Key.Rationale: This option is a misinterpretation of the given simile and does not support the context provided in the sentence.

C.Choice: something that is easy to see

Key.Rationale: “Plain as day” means that something is easy to see.

D.Choice: something that is warm and bright

Key.Rationale: This option is a misinterpretation of the given simile and does not support the context provided in the sentence.

SubTopics: Demonstrate understanding of figurative language, word relationships, and nuances in word meanings.
Content: Which word is a synonym for r͟a͟v͟i͟n͟e?

A.Choice: bird

Key.Rationale: This option is not a synonym for “ravine.”

B.Choice: boulder

Key.Rationale: This option is not a synonym for “ravine.”

C.Choice: ditch

Key.Rationale: A “ravine” is a narrow steep- sided valley.

D.Choice: meadow

Key.Rationale: This option is not a synonym for “ravine.”

SubTopics: Quote accurately from a text when explaining what the text says explicitly and when drawing inferences and/or making generalizations from the text.
Content: Which sentence from the passage best shows that Scooter’s soccer skills are equal to the combined skills of the children?

A.Choice: “One against three was pretty fair.”

Key.Rationale: The sentence is trying to show that Scooter’s skills are equal to those of the three children.

B.Choice: “Having four legs, instead of two, he was a lot quicker than Adelee and me as well.”

Key.Rationale: The sentence compares Scooter to the children but does not support the inference.

C.Choice: “If we didn’t pay any attention, he’d sit down on my foot.”

Key.Rationale: This option does not relate to the given inference.

D.Choice: “When we took a break, Button would show up.”

Key.Rationale: This option does not relate to the given inference.

SubTopics: Determine a theme of a story, drama, or poem from details in the text, including how characters in a story or drama respond to challenges or how the speaker in a poem reflects upon a topic; summarize the text.
Content: Read the sentence from the passage.
:box:“But while I was waiting, I sure had fun with my pups.”
Which theme does the sentence best support?

A.Choice: Soccer is a challenging sport for children to learn.

Key.Rationale: This option is not a theme being conveyed in the passage.

B.Choice: It is unusual for a dog to know how to kick a ball.

Key.Rationale: This option is not a theme being conveyed in the passage.

C.Choice: It can be dangerous to ride a bike on gravel roads.

Key.Rationale: This option is not a theme being conveyed in the passage.

D.Choice: Spending time with pets can be very rewarding.

Key.Rationale: The main character spends time with Scooter and Button and the dogs show their appreciation after the bicycle accident.

SubTopics: Demonstrate understanding of figurative language, word relationships, and nuances in word meanings.
Content: This question has two parts. Answer Part One and then answer Part Two.
In paragraph 24, what does the idiom “blue in the face” suggest?

A.Choice: peace

Key.Rationale: This emotion is not supported by the context of the passage.

B.Choice: jealousy

Key.Rationale: This emotion is not supported by the context of the passage.

C.Choice: happiness

Key.Rationale: This emotion is not supported by the context of the passage.

D.Choice: frustration

Key.Rationale: “Blue in the face” suggests that the main character is frustrated when trying to get Button’s attention.

Content: What phrase in paragraph 24 best supports the answer in Part One? Choose one answer.

A.Choice: “. . . interesting smell in the grass.”

Key.Rationale: This option does not support the idea that the speaker is frustrated when calling Button’s name.

B.Choice: “...his head went down, ...”

Key.Rationale: This option does not support the idea that the speaker is frustrated when calling Button’s name.

C.Choice: “...his nose worked so hard...”

Key.Rationale: This option does not support the idea that the speaker is frustrated when calling Button’s name.

D.Choice: “. . . he never so much as looked up.”

Key.Rationale: Button “never so much as looked up” when the main character called for Button to come.

SubTopics: Compare and contrast two or more characters, settings, or events in a story, drama, or poem, drawing on specific details in the text (e.g., how characters interact).
Content: This question has two parts. Answer Part One and then answer Part Two.
How are Button and Scooter different from one another?

A.Choice: Scooter is interested in treats, but Button is not.

Key.Rationale: “With Scooter all I had to do was stick my hand in my pocket, like I was digging” and “Button couldn’t care less about treats” both help the reader conclude that Scooter liked treats and Button did not.

B.Choice: Scooter likes to play outside, but Button does not.

Key.Rationale: This option is not supported by details in the passage.

C.Choice: Button likes to get praise, but Scooter does not.

Key.Rationale: This option is not supported by details in the passage.

D.Choice: Button is eager to run on the hills, but Scooter is not.

Key.Rationale: This option is not supported by details in the passage.

Content: What two quotes from the passage support the answer in Part One? Choose two answers.

A.Choice: “. . . bird dogs weren’t supposed to bark; . . .”

Key.Rationale: Although “bird dogs weren’t supposed to bark” describes a characteristic about dogs like Button, this option does not support the comparison in Part One.

B.Choice: “... all I had to do was stick my hand in my pocket, ...”

Key.Rationale: This detail shows what Scooter and Button liked.

C.Choice: “. . . liked being petted and loved . . .”

Key.Rationale: This detail shows what Scooter and Button liked.

D.Choice: “. . . the problem was my whistling.”

Key.Rationale: This option refers to the narrator rather than the dogs.
This option shows how the dogs are similar rather than different.

SubTopics: Draw evidence from literary or informational texts to support analysis, reflection, and/or research.
Content: In the drama, the Fisherman and the Empoeror are minor characters. Write an essay analyzing how the Fisherman and the Emperor are improtant to the development of a theme of the drama. Use evidence from the drama to support your response.

SubTopics: Explain the function of conjunctions, prepositions, and interjections in general and their function in particular sentences.
Content: Read the sentence.
:box:It seems that just about everybody e͟x͟c͟e͟p͟t Dan enjoys eating fruits l͟i͟k͟e apples and bananas, y͟e͟t Dan says he enjoys eating less common types of fruit, such a͟s kiwis and mangoes.
Which underlined word functions as a conjunction in the sentence?

A.Choice: except

Key.Rationale: This option functions as a preposition.

B.Choice: like

Key.Rationale: This option functions as a preposition.

C.Choice: yet

Key.Rationale: “Yet” is functioning as a coordinating conjunction joining two independent clauses.

D.Choice: as

Key.Rationale: This option functions as a preposition.

SubTopics: Recognize and correct inappropriate shifts in verb tense.
Content: Which sentence is written correctly?

A.Choice: Before he left the building, Jasper checked to make sure he has locked the doors.

Key.Rationale: This option introduces an inappropriate shift in verb tense.

B.Choice: Before he left the building, Jasper checked to make sure he had locked the doors.

Key.Rationale: This option uses the past perfect tense (“had locked”) appropriately to signal an action prior to Jasper leaving the building.

C.Choice: Before he left the building, Jasper checks to make sure he locked the doors.

Key.Rationale: This option introduces an inappropriate shift in verb tense.

D.Choice: Before he left the building, Jasper has checked to make sure he had locked the doors.

Key.Rationale: This option introduces an inappropriate shift in verb tense.

SubTopics: Use punctuation to separate items in a series.
Content: Choose the correct way to use commas in the sentence.

A.Choice: Pennsylvania has many historic bridges built for train, automobile, or foot traffic across the state’s many rivers streams and valleys.

Key.Rationale: This sentence does not correctly use commas to separate items in a series.

B.Choice: Pennsylvania, has many historic bridges, built for train, automobile or foot traffic across the state’s many rivers streams, and valleys.

Key.Rationale: This sentence does not correctly use commas to separate items in a series.

C.Choice: Pennsylvania has many historic bridges built for train, automobile, or foot traffic across the state’s many rivers streams, and valleys.

Key.Rationale: This sentence does not correctly use commas to separate items in a series.

D.Choice: Pennsylvania has many historic bridges built for train, automobile, or foot traffic across the state’s many rivers, streams, and valleys.

Key.Rationale: Commas are used to correctly separate the items in a series.

SubTopics: Use underlining, quotation marks, or italics to indicate titles of works.
Content: Which sentence shows the correct use of italics?

A.Choice: A Wrinkle in Time is Madeleine L’Engle’s book about children visiting other planets.

Key.Rationale: The words in the title of L’Engle’s book are italicized.

B.Choice: The article Art in the 1920s helped students understand the time period they were studying.

Key.Rationale: Titles of articles should be placed in quotation marks.

C.Choice: We read the chapter called Habitat of Turtles to complete our report about where turtles live.

Key.Rationale: Titles of chapters should be placed in quotation marks.

D.Choice: The short story Amazing Leonardo da Vinci inspired students to create their own inventions.

Key.Rationale: Titles of short stories should be placed in quotation marks.

SubTopics: Write opinion pieces on topics or texts, supporting a point of view with reasons and information.
Content:
:box:If you were asked to write a report, which would you rather use, a pencil, a pen, or a computer? Consider the advantages of your choice.

Write an essay for your teacher that states your opinion on which writing tool, a pencil, a pen, or a computer, is the best to use and why. Be sure to use details and reasons to support your opinion.
